title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Six states including Texas and Florida will gain seats in the US House of Representatives when congressional districts are redrawn this year under new census data that underscore the growing political clout of states in the south and west and the waning influence of those in the north-east and Midwest.

The Census Bureau on Monday released 2020 census data showing that the US population rose to 331,449,281 in 2020, a 7.4 per cent increase since 2010, when the previous census was conducted.

The data illustrated how quickly some parts of the country have grown relative to others over the past decade. The population grew 10.2 per cent in the south from 2010-20, according to the Census Bureau, compared with 9.2 per cent in the west, 4.1 per cent in the north-east and 3.1 per cent in the Midwest.

The numbers hold political significance because they will be used to reallocate the 435 congressional districts ahead of next year's midterm elections. Democrats control the House by a margin of just six seats.

The Census Bureau said that, because of the population shifts, Texas will gain two seats in the House; Colorado, Florida, Montana, North Carolina and Oregon will each gain one; and seven states — California, Illinois, Michigan, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia — will each lose one.

Coronavirus digest

  • The White House has announced that the US will share up to 60m doses of the Oxford/AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine with other countries. Demand is likely to be high from India, where security forces have been called in to help tackle a devastating second wave of coronavirus, although manufacturing problems in the US look set to delay shipments by several weeks.

  • The EU and US are in talks over a pass scheme that would encourage summer tourism by vaccinated American travellers.

  • Novartis has warned of a worrying delay in cancer diagnoses because of the coronavirus pandemic. The Swiss drugmaker missed earnings and sales expectations in the first quarter as the pandemic hit demand for drugs for breast cancer, skin and eye conditions.

  • The speed with which Covid-19 has overwhelmed India's health systems has sparked alarm over a new variant. The FT View is that aiding India is not just a moral imperative but a matter of self-interest. Prime minister Narendra Modi is paying the price for declaring victory too early, writes Gideon Rachman.

Employers are in for a wave of post-pandemic litigation as lawyers predict a jump in pandemic protection and discrimination lawsuits, writes Patti Waldmeir. Follow the latest on our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

In the news

White House gears up for tax fight rises Joe Biden's top economic adviser said there was “no evidence” that raising capital gains taxes would hurt long-term investment, as the White House seeks to impose higher levies on the richest Americans. Can Biden transform the US economy with long-term investment while addressing climate change and narrowing income inequality and racial disparities? This is the first in a series on the US president's first 100 days in office.

California governor to face recall election California governor Gavin Newsom will face a recall election this year, as frustration mounts over the Democrat's handling of the coronavirus pandemic. The California secretary of state's office said on Monday that it had verified enough signatures on a petition to force what will be only the second recall in the history of the most populous US state.

Nomura posts $2.9bn Archegos loss Nomura has said its total loss from the implosion of Archegos Capital, the family office run by trader Bill Hwang, will hit almost $2.9bn. The hit helped drive the Japanese bank to a quarterly loss of $1.4bn, its biggest since the 2008 global financial crisis. Meanwhile Swiss bank UBS also announced today that it had lost $774m from trades linked to Hwang.

EU to charge Apple EU competition chief Margrethe Vestager will this week publicly issue charges against technology giant Apple over concerns that its rules for developers on its App store break EU law. The move follows a complaint from music streaming app Spotify.

  • Ten months after Apple promised “enhanced privacy features” for iPhones, the changes have finally arrived with iOS 14.5. The software update, which could transform the way apps make money, has sparked fury among some developers.

Maersk doubles profit guidance Shares in AP Moller-Maersk have risen as the world's largest container shipping group nearly doubled its 2021 profit guidance. The updated forecast reflects the disruption and soaring prices caused by the closure of the Suez Canal, with Maersk predicting that the effects will be felt for most of this year.

HSBC profit rises 79% Bank HSBC said its first-quarter net profit climbed 79 per cent as reserves for bad loans shrunk and an improving economic outlook more than a year into the coronavirus pandemic partly offset the hit to revenues from low interest rates.

BP beats forecasts Forecast-beating first-quarter results from BP have put the oil company on track to restart share buybacks. The British energy major posted a $2.6bn underlying profit for the first three months of 2021, jumping from $791m the year before and well ahead of the consensus forecast of $1.6bn.

Chinese fundraising in US hits record Funds raised by Chinese groups on US equity markets surged 440 per cent in the opening months of 2021, as the allure of sky-high Wall Street valuations outweighed the threat of forced delistings under a US audit law.

The day ahead

US tech earnings Microsoft and Google parent Alphabet kick off a big week for Silicon Valley earnings. Pinterest and chipmakers AMD and NXP also report.

  • Other companies releasing earnings: 3M, Advanced Micro Devices, Amgen, Centene, Ecolab, Eli Lilly, Fiserv, General Electric, Illumina, Marsh & McLennan Companies, Mondelez International, Roper Industries, Sherwin-Williams, Starbucks, Stryker, Texas Instruments, UPS, Vale, Visa, Waste Management, Focusrite and PZ Cussons.

Fed meets The Federal Reserve begins a two-day policy meeting amid a rapidly accelerating economic recovery. The US will also have consumer confidence data for April out.

Brexit trade deal vote The European parliament will vote on ratifying the UK-EU Brexit trade deal agreed in December on Tuesday.

What else we're reading

Can prosecutors flip Donald Trump's ‘eyes and ears'? Facing perils on multiple fronts, the legal question haunting the former president is whether Allen Weisselberg, the Trump Organization's chief financial officer, will betray the family to whom he has devoted his adult life.

AI at work isn't always intelligent Daunted by the thought of losing visibility over staff during Covid-19, some employers panic-bought software to surveil them, much of which claims to use artificial intelligence to measure productivity. Such technology is not always bad, only when it is dumb — which is often, writes Sarah O'Connor.

Chile's critical test A plethora of little-known candidates has created uncertainty over elections next month for a constitutional assembly, which will replace the charter that dates from the military dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet. President Sebastián Piñera, who will step down next year, has faced an earthquake, riots and Covid-19, but wants to be remembered for laying the foundations for prosperity. For more stories on Chile, see the FT's new Investing in Chile special report.

How to fix the housing crisis An FT survey of young people from Hong Kong to London found that housing costs were among their biggest concerns. The most crucial issue is the inadequate supply, including affordable housing. The shift from company pensions to the individualism and insecurity of defined contribution schemes is also coming at a cost to the young.

Anatomy of a hedge fund hack The FT has pieced together the details of how an attack unfolded on a London-based private investor who works with smaller financial companies across Europe, and how a separate phishing attack forced the liquidation of the main fund run by Levitas Capital, a Sydney-based company with $75m in assets under management.

Gambling with Armageddon The Cuban missile crisis has been dissected many times before. But according to critic Victor Sebestyen, Serhii Plokhy's Nuclear Folly is arguably “the most authoritative and cleverly written” account yet of the “bad judgment calls and worse information-gathering” that, in late 1962, led the world to the brink of catastrophe.

Meet our journalists: Christine Zhang  

Christine Zhang is a data reporter for the FT in New York. She covers US news stories using data analysis, graphics and statistics on the FT's visual and data journalism team. 

What is a story you are particularly interested in right now? After a year in which data journalism dominated the headlines, I've been thinking more and more about all the things data don't show — particularly the communities that data often obscure. An example close to my heart was outlined in my recent piece about the data invisibility of Asian Americans.

What's your favourite newsletter? I'm far from a sports aficionado, but I often read Scoreboard to learn more about the business perspective of sports (plus sports analyses can feature some amazing data and graphics). Sign up here to receive Scoreboard on Saturdays.

What film have you seen recently that you'd recommend? Coded Bias, an introduction into how algorithms used in everyday life can perpetuate longstanding societal inequities.

And the best book you read this year? The Hidden Girl and Other Stories, a collection of science fiction short stories by Ken Liu. For a taste of Liu's amazing writing, check out Ghost Days and Seven Birthdays, both featured in the book.
